questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Kawasaki disease?
questions.solution: KEY TAKEAWAYS: Kawasaki disease is a rare, inflammatory condition that primarily affects children under 5 years old. It causes inflammation in the blood vessels, particularly the coronary arteries, which supply blood to the heart. Symptoms include high fever lasting more than five days, rash, swollen lymph nodes, red eyes, red, cracked lips, and a "strawberry" tongue.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy, is brought to OPD. He has had a high temperature for the last week. His mother has taken him to the general practitioner on two occasions and he has completed a course of amoxicillin. His eyes are injected and his throat is red. He has marked cervical lymphadenopathy. The skin on his fingers has started to peel. Everyone else in the family is well. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The child fulfils the major diagnostic criteria for KD
  • Option C: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome has areas of denuded skin as well as fever and malaise.
  • Option D: Scarlet fever has inflammation of the throat but usually a generalized maculopapular rash. This may be followed by peeling of the skin of fingers and toes.
  • Option A: Failure to respond to antibiotics might make you consider tuberculosis but his clinical features, especially peeling of the skin, do not fit this diagnosis.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Kawasaki disease is a rare, inflammatory condition that primarily affects children under 5 years old. It causes inflammation in the blood vessels, particularly the coronary arteries, which supply blood to the heart. Symptoms include high fever lasting more than five days, rash, swollen lymph nodes, red eyes, red, cracked lips, and a "strawberry" tongue.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common complication associated with Kawasaki disease?
questions.solution:
• Most common complication associated with KD is Myocarditis. It might be asymptomatic or present with congestive cardiac failure.
  • Most common cause of death is Thrombosis of Coronary artery aneurysm (CAA).

Other complications include:

  • Kawasaki disease shock syndrome
  • Mitral regurgitation
  • Asymptomatic pericardial effusion

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Myocarditis, or inflammation of the heart muscle, is a recognized complication of Kawasaki disease. It occurs due to the widespread inflammation in blood vessels and heart tissue that characterizes the disease. Myocarditis in Kawasaki disease can lead to symptoms such as rapid or irregular heartbeat, chest pain, fatigue, and in severe cases, heart failure.

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with Kawasaki disease and is given a dose of IVIG and aspirin. After 48 hours of dose, the high-grade fever continues. Which of the following is not a treatment option?
questions.solution:
• IVIG-resistant Kawasaki disease occurs when a patient with Kawasaki disease does not respond to initial treatment with intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG).
  • Typically, children with Kawasaki disease are treated with a single dose of IVIG and aspirin, which reduces inflammation and lowers the risk of complications. However, about 10-20% of children do not respond to IVIG treatment, continuing to have fever and signs of inflammation after treatment.
  • IVIG-resistant Kawasaki disease increases the risk of coronary artery complications, as persistent inflammation can damage the heart's blood vessels. In these cases, alternative treatments may be used, including:
    • Corticosteroids (such as methylprednisolone)
    • Infliximab or other tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitors
    • Other immunosuppressive agents, such as cyclosporine or methotrexate, in severe cases

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The child is suffering from IVIG resistant KD which is defined as non-resolution of fever 36 hours after infusion of complete dose of IVIG.

questions.text:
A 5 year old child, presents to you as she has been unwell for 2 weeks with lethargy, fever and painful wrists and knees. On examination she has a temperature of 38.5° C and a subtle erythematous rash on her trunk. You identify that several joints are swollen, warm, and painful to move, including the wrists, her right elbow, the knees, her left ankle and left hip. She has some cervical lymphadenopathy and her spleen is palpable. You perform some blood tests and get the following results:

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Systemic-onset juvenile idiopathic arthritis is the most likely diagnosis, as she has a systemic illness, polyarthritis (more than four joints) and a salmon-pink rash. The raised neutrophil count and markedly raised ESR are consistent with the diagnosis.

Criteria for the Classification of Juvenile Rheumatoid Arthritis

  • Age at onset: <16 years
  • Arthritis (swelling or effusion, or the presence of ≥2 of the following signs: limitation of range of motion, tenderness or pain on motion, increased heat) in ≥1 joint
  • Duration of disease: ≥6 weeks
  • Onset type defined by type of articular involvement in the 1st 6 months after onset:
    • Polyarthritis: ≥5 inflamed joints
    • Oligoarthritis: ≤4 inflamed joints
    • Systemic-onset disease: arthritis with rash and a characteristic quotidian fever
  • Exclusion of other forms of juvenile arthritis

Option A: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia needs to be considered, but is less likely as the child has numerous joints affected and the blood film is normal.

Option B: Post-streptococcal arthritis is unlikely as the antistreptolysin O titre is normal, although a repeat blood test is required to confirm that the titre remains low.

Option C: SLE may have similar clinical features but is unlikely as the ANA (antinuclear antibody) and double-stranded DNA are negative. SLE is also very uncommon at this age.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA) is the most common type of arthritis in children, characterized by persistent joint inflammation lasting more than six weeks in children under 16, with no identifiable cause ("idiopathic"). JIA can cause joint pain, swelling, warmth, and stiffness, particularly in the morning or after inactivity.

questions.text: A 3 1/2 years old child presents to you with a 24-hour history of a limp and pain in her left thigh. There is no history of trauma. Her temperature is 38.9° C and her pulse is 150 beats/min. On examination the left thigh is swollen and held flexed and abducted. She holds it as still as possible and cries if it is moved. The upper leg is slightly red and is warmer to touch than the right leg. She has no other medical history and her mother has given some paracetamol, which had no effect on the pain. What is the likely cause of the clinical condition?
questions.solution:
• The child has very acute history and flexed and abducted position of the thigh at rest suggest septic arthritis. Ultrasound (and diagnostic aspiration), blood tests for culture and tests for inflammatory markers should be performed and intravenous antibiotics started.
  • Septic arthritis, also known as infectious arthritis, is a joint infection typically caused by bacteria (often Staphylococcus aureus) but can also be caused by viruses or fungi.
  • The infection leads to inflammation within the joint, causing symptoms like sudden, severe joint pain, swelling, warmth, redness, and restricted movement, often accompanied by fever. It most commonly affects large joints like the knee, hip, shoulder, or elbow.

Option B: Reactive arthritis has no fever and usually has a history of infective illness in recent past.

Option C: There is no history of trauma for diagnosing fracture.

Option D: JIA has chronic illness more than 6 weeks of fever and pain.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Septic arthritis, also known as infectious arthritis is a joint infection typically caused by bacteria (often Staphylococcus aureus), causing symptoms like sudden, severe joint pain, swelling, warmth, redness, and restricted movement, often accompanied by fever.

questions.text: The most common bony finding on a skeletal radiograph in JIA is which of the following?
questions.solution:
X-ray findings in JIA include:

  • Soft Tissue Swelling: Early in the disease, x-rays may show signs of soft tissue swelling around the affected joints, which is a sign of inflammation.
  • Osteopenia (Bone Density Loss): Decreased bone density, particularly around the inflamed joints, can appear early due to inflammation and reduced use of the joint.
  • Joint Space Narrowing: Chronic inflammation leads to cartilage loss, resulting in reduced space between bones in the joint. This is often seen in more advanced cases.
  • Bony Erosions: In some cases of aggressive JIA, particularly polyarticular and systemic types, inflammation can cause bony erosions or small areas where bone is destroyed near the joint.
  • Growth Disturbances: In children, chronic inflammation in a joint can interfere with normal bone growth, potentially leading to limb-length discrepancies, joint deformities, or growth plate abnormalities.
  • Fusion of Joints (Ankylosis): In severe or untreated cases, the joint can undergo fusion or ankylosis, where the bones grow together, limiting movement. This is particularly noted in the spine or wrist joints in certain types of JIA.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The most common finding on radiograph is normal bone and joint, followed by periarticular osteopenia. Noting osteopenia on radiograph, however, implies that over 50% of the bone mineral content has been lost due to the inflammation.

Other findings, such as joint space narrowing, periosteal new bone formation, and most ominous, erosions, are late findings in JIA.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl presents with difficulty in going upstairs and leg pains. She is always tired, feels hot and has had some weight loss. The family doctor has seen her on several occasions for eczema that appears on her face and hands. It will disappear and come back within days, even without treatment. The muscle enzyme is 1500 mmol/l, and ESR is 90, with thrombocytosis. Lactate dehydrogenase is high, as is ANA.
questions.solution:
• Juvenile dermatomyositis is the most common inflammatory myopathy in children. It can progress slowly with fatiguability, a low-grade fever and loss of weight, all of which are common.
  • The rash usually appears first over exposed areas, followed by proximal weakness. Periorbital violaceous (heliotropic) erythema occurs across the nasal bridge and around the eyelids. It may involve the upper torso, hands and especially the knuckles. Facial edema is common.
  • Creatinine kinase will be very high, and aldolase, serum aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) will be high, but not specific. An MRI scan is also helpful in diagnosis by using T2-weighted images and fat suppression. This will show the active site of the disease, helping muscle biopsy and EMG testing.
  • Corticosteroids, methotrexate and cyclosporine can be used in management. Long-term complications are calcification and calcified nodules with cardiomyopathies.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Dermatomyositis is a rare autoimmune disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash, often purple in color, affecting areas like the eyelids and knuckles. It primarily impacts the shoulders, hips, and thighs, making everyday movements difficult. Treatment includes corticosteroids and immunosuppressive drugs to control inflammation and prevent muscle damage.

questions.text: A 5 years old presents with a swollen joint. Her knee joint has been swollen for several days. There is some mild tenderness but she continues to walk, with a slight limp. Her mother reports that 3 weeks ago she had a bout of gastroenteritis associated with a fever. There were two episodes of bloody diarrhoea and she vomited once. Her symptoms resolved without treatment. On examination she is afebrile. Her right knee is swollen with only mild tenderness on passive movements of the joint. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Reactive arthritis is a type of inflammatory arthritis that develops in response to an infection in another part of the body, commonly in the urinary tract, gastrointestinal tract, or respiratory system. It typically occurs after infections caused by bacteria like Chlamydia, Salmonella, Shigella, or Campylobacter.

Key Features:

  1. Joint Symptoms: It often affects the knees, ankles, and feet, causing pain, swelling, and stiffness. It is usually asymmetric, meaning it may only affect one side of the body.
  2. Enthesitis: Inflammation at the sites where tendons and ligaments attach to bones, especially in the heels, can be a hallmark.
  3. Conjunctivitis and Urethritis: Many patients also experience eye inflammation (conjunctivitis) and urinary symptoms (urethritis), which are part of the condition's classic triad (Reiter's syndrome).
  4. Skin Manifestations: Skin rashes, including keratoderma blennorrhagicum (scaly lesions on the soles of the feet and palms), can occur.

Option B: Septic arthritis has acute history of fever and limited joint movement with other signs of joint inflammation.

Option C: HUS has characteristic presentation with the triad of acute renal failure, microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia and thrombocytopenia.

Option D: Rickets has no pain or swelling.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: This is the most common cause of acute hip pain in children. It occurs in children aged 2-12 years of age. It often follows or is accompanied by a viral infection. Presentation is with sudden onset of pain in the hip or a limp. There is no pain at rest, but there is decreased range of movement, particularly external rotation.
